content.text: A thermometer is placed on the bench so that room temperature can be measured
Read and record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) as shown on the thermometer in Fig. 1.2
A student pours hot water into the beaker so that the level is as shown in Fig. 1.1
In Table 1.1, he then records the temperatures \(\theta\) every minute as the water cools until time \(t = 6\) minutes
Complete the column headings and complete the time column in Table 1.1
thermometer bulb near the bottom of the beaker
thermometer bulb near the surface of the water
State in which position of the thermometer bulb the average rate of cooling is the greater
Justify your answer by referring to the results
position
justification
What precaution do the results suggest should be taken when measuring the temperature of a liquid?
Explain how the results show that this is a sensible precaution
precaution
explanation
A student in a different school wants to repeat the experiment in order to check the results
Suggest two experimental conditions which should be kept the same
Some IGCSE students are investigating the cooling of water
Fig. 1.1 shows how the apparatus is set up
Describe a precaution which the IGCSE students might have taken in order to measure \(h\) as accurately as possible. You may draw a diagram
Measure, and record in Table 2.1, the height \(h\) in each experiment
The diagrams are drawn to 1/5 scale
Calculate, and record in Table 2.1, the actual heights \(H\) of the pendulum bob above the bench
Figs. 2.3 to 2.7 are scale diagrams showing the height \(h\) of the pendulum bob above
bench for each of the five experiments
bench
Fig. 2.3 Fig. 2.4 Fig. 2.5 Fig. 2.6 Fig. 2.7
For each value of height \(h\), calculate the time \(T\) for one complete oscillation the equation \(T = \frac{l}{10}\) . Record these values in Table 2.1
Calculate the values of \(T^2\) and record these in the table
Plot a graph of \(T^2 /s^2\) (y-axis) against \(H / \text{cm}\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph
Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
G =
One of the students wishes to carry out the experiment again to obtain results with more reliable
Describe one change she might make to the method to achieve this
The IGCSE class is investigating the oscillation of a pendulum
The apparatus is set up as shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.2
The height \(h\) of the pendulum bob above the bench is measured and recorded
This is repeated, to obtain a total of five different values of \(h\), by shortening the string of the pendulum but without changing the height of the clamp
For each value of \(h\), the pendulum bob is pulled to one side by a small distance, as shown in Fig. 2.2
The pendulum is then released and the time \(t\) for 10 complete oscillations is measured and recorded
The current in the circuit and the potential difference across the combination of lamps connected between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\) are to be measured
On Fig. 3.1, draw the symbol for a voltmeter, connected to measure the potential difference \(V\) between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\)
Calculate, and record in the table, the total resistance \(R\) of each combination of lamps, using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Complete the column headings in the table
The values of potential difference \(V\) across AB and current \(I\) for circuit 1 are in Table 3.1
The lamps are then reconnected as shown in Fig. 3.2 and then Fig. 3.3 and the experiment is repeated
If each of the lamps had the same resistance, the total resistance of the lamp circuit 3 would be twice the total resistance of the lamps in circuit 1
State whether the results in the table show this to be the case. Justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
An IGCSE student wants to measure the potential difference across the lamp marked **L** in **circuit 2**
On the diagram for **circuit 2**, Fig. 3.2, show how a voltmeter should be connected to measure this potential difference.
Students in the IGCSE class are investigating the resistance of electric circuits with branches
The apparatus has been set up as shown in Fig. 3.1
Read and record the volume \(V_{1}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder shown in Fig. 4.1
Read and record the volume \(V_{2}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder shown in Fig. 4.2
The student then uses a balance to measure the mass \(m\) of the object, as shown
Fig. 4.3
Calculate the density of the object using the equation
density =   .........
Suggest a possible practical cause of inaccuracy in this method
The IGCSE class has been asked to determine the density of an object
One student is finding the volume of the object using a measuring cylinder containing water in which the object is to be placed
The measuring cylinder containing only water is shown in Fig. 4.1
The measuring cylinder after the object has been placed in the water is shown in Fig. 4.2
Fig. 4.2
On Fig. 5.1, carefully measure \(u\) and record the value
On Fig. 5.1, carefully measure \(d\), the distance between the illuminated triangle and the screen when the image is sharp, and record the value
Calculate a value \(m\) for the magnification, using your answers to (a)(i) and (a)(ii), and the equation \(m = \frac{d - u}{u}\)
m =
The illuminated triangle is shown in Fig. 5.2. The image of the triangle seen on the screen is shown in Fig. 5.3
A student says that the values of \(m\) and \(M\) should be the same
State whether your findings support this. Justify your answer by reference to your results for \(m\) and \(M\)
statement
justification
Describe one difficulty the students might have found when measuring the of the image on the screen
Suggest a solution for the problem
difficulty
solution
Suggest one further precaution which should be taken to make the experiment reliable
IGCSE students are investigating the magnification produced by a converging lens
The apparatus is set up as shown below
The screen is moved until a sharp image of the object is seen on the screen
